body.p: Rienzi was the most successful of Mary Russell Mitford's plays. If Our Village is Mitford's lasting contribution to the journalistic sensibilities of the Victorians, perhaps it is Rienzi that most dramatically showcases her clear ties to the fading world of the Romantics. We should recall that Mitford was Byron's senior by little more than a month, and she was forty by the time Rienzi appeared on the stage. Rienzi draws from several of the major currents of Romanticism. It could be read in the context of the Romantic revival of Shakespeare, as it was refracted into its many hues from the performances under the scholarly direction of John Kemble, to the passionate portrayals of Sarah Siddons, to the commentaries by Coleridge, Hazlitt, De Quincy, and the Lambs, to the visionary art of Fuseli. All of these Romantic returns to the Bard were drawn together by a growing attention to language and the psychological aspects of Shakespeare's plays. Not only does Rienzi echo moments from Macbeth and Romeo and Juliet it is guided by the Romantic reinterpretation of the Elizabethan giant: to be as dazzling in the theater of the mind as on the stage. Similarly, Rienzi could be read as belonging to the Romantic fascination with Rome and Italy, with clear links to the worlds of Percy Shelley's Cenci, Keats's Isabella, or Gibbon's history, from which Mitford directly takes her tale. Indeed, Mitford's first three plays--of which Rienzi is the third--were Italian dramas. Italy, particularly medieval Italy, provided the Romantics some affordable distance when discussing dangerous political issues, and it was not until Mitford turned to English history, in Charles the First, that she ran afoul of the licenser. And, of course, Mitford's Rienzi might also be located in the Age of Revolutions, when the moral ambiguities inherent in any social struggle so often took center stage, as it does in Southey and Coleridge's early drama The Fall of Robespierre, or Wordsworth's Prelude, Percy Shelley's Revolt of Islam. The eighteenth century invented the modern revolution, but it was the early nineteenth that developed the common vocabulary through which revolutions were understood. Therefore, Rienzi comes to us not only a historical tragedy but a drama mediated by multiple historical traditions; yet, even if we take the time to discover Rienzi possessed by the spirits of its own age, its familiar conflicts and insistent humanism make it among the most accessible dramas of the Romantic period for twenty-first-century readers and audiences.

In the play, Rienzi, a bureaucratic functionary of low birth, leads a popular revolution that unseats the noble families of Rome. It is a revolutionary drama, but the insurrectionary moment is of little interest to Mitford; the coup is bloodless and occurs off stage between the first and second acts. Mitford's Rienzi is about the days following the revolution: the political struggle to secure the revolution by either folding the families of the old regime into the new State or cleansing the State through Terror. After confronting the impossibility of the former task, Cola di Rienzi is compelled to the latter, but the play's moral intelligence emerges from its refusal to indulge in an obtuse ethics that removes Terror from the context of Virtue. Even as a Terrorist, Rienzi remains the play's tragic hero. Yet, Mitford invites her audience to challenge their heroes, and Rienzi's greatness is continually crosscut by nagging questions about his ambition, pride, demagoguery, desire for revenge, perhaps even his sanity. Like is so often in the case in the study of history, Rienzi encourages us to analyze the failure of revolutions by examining the tragic faults of those who led them.

As I have already mentioned, Mitford's telling was inspired by Gibbon's The History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire (1776-89). At times she stays remarkably close to Gibbon's text. For example, Rienzi's homely origins and the haughty oath he forces the Roman nobles to take are little more than Gibbon's account recast into blank verse. At many other points, however, Mitford has radically filtered Gibbon's history for the stage. The historical Rienzi actually led two revolutions which Mitford distills into a single revolt, leaving aside the political complexities attending each. Similarly, Mitford removes the ambiguities surrounding the actual Rienzi's religious positioning, which alternated between defender of the Papacy and patriotic paganism. Her Rienzi unambiguously harkens to old pagan Rome from the first. Often, though, Mitford invents. The two female characters (Claudia and Lady Colonna), and the subplots they advance, are completely Mitford's. So too is the wedding scene that drives the third act, and the play's ending, which turns its back on both the events and the tone of Gibbon's account. Claudia and Lady Colonna are, in fact, central to the narrative that Mitford turns, a history that is more familial than political, more personal than institutional.

The whims of the licenser and the caprices of actor-managers made getting a drama to one of the respected stages in London a routine challenge, but Rienzi's journey was particularly arduous. During the autumn of 1822, having recently completed Foscari and while finishing revisions for Julian, Mitford first conceived of a drama based on the career of Cola di Rienzi. The following spring, in the midst of writing sketches for the magazines, she confided her interest in composing a historical tragedy about Rienzi to William Macready, who was at that moment playing the lead in Julian. Noting Rienzi's potential as a character and his resemblance to Napoleon in the trajectory of his rise and fall, Mitford felt there was dramatic potential in Gibbon's account. Despite her hopes, theatrical infighting between Macready and Charles Kemble dimmed the play's prospects by the summer of 1823, and she felt compelled to put the project aside for several months. By the summer of 1824, however, Mitford was back in discussions with Macready over Rienzi, and, in November, she brought a manuscript to London for his approval. Macready wanted Mitford to make significant alterations. Moreover, he indicated that if the play was to be staged as soon as he wanted, she had only two weeks to complete the revisions. Mitford hurried to meet Macready's demands (composing a new first act, combining the second and third, and rewriting the fifth act completely) but was disappointed when Macready seemed to reverse himself and informed her that not only would Drury Lane not produce Rienzi that season, but that it was likely that it never would. Mitford offered Rienzi to Kemble at Covent Garden, who initially accepted it but then advised her to withdraw the piece, all without explanation. It was then, in June of 1825, that an anonymous letter in Blackwood's Magazine attacked Macready for his mistreatment of Mitford and her play. Macready was furious and held the letter against Mitford.

Rienzi, thus, languished on the shelf for several years. Frances Trollope thought highly of the manuscript and unsuccessfully attempted to persuade Edmund Kean and Macready to stage it. Meanwhile, Mitford advanced her career as an author: Foscari at last found a receptive audience at Covent Garden, Dramatic Scenes, Sonnets, and Other Poems was published, and three volumes of Our Village brought Mitford to the public's attention. By the time Rienzi appeared, Mitford had already established herself as a professional author.

Rienzi finally debuted at Drury Lane on October 4, 1828, with Charles Young, the esteemed tragedian, in the title role. The play was an unqualified success, running for thirty-four nights (more than doubling the run of Foscari), and selling more than eight thousand copies before the year ended. It also earned Mitford more than Â£400. More importantly, the triumph of Rienzi raised Mitford's reputation among the literary elite. The critics were in agreement that Rienzi was not only Mitford's best work to date but that it was a work of some poetic genius; even Macready offered his praises. By December, Mitford had won over London's fickle literati.

Rienzi continued to be influential throughout the nineteenth century. After its initial run, it continued in the repertory of Drury Lane. It was known in continental Europe, and a German imprint, which, with some restored lines from the manuscript, was available by 1837. It was also successful in America, with performances in New York theaters well into the 1880s. Many of Mitford's inventions, including the star-crossed lovers and the centrality of the Colonna family, were retained by Bulwer-Lytton in his novel, Rienzi, the Last of the Roman Tribunes (1835), and were then carried over into Wagner's opera of the same name (1842).

Comparison of the three editions presented here provide some indication of the play's complicated development. The manuscript, submitted to the Office of the Lord Chamberlain in September 1828, and in Mitford's own hand, is the earliest text of the play that we have, and it provides some interesting insights into how the play evolved. A few long passages from the character of Rienzi, some even explaining his motivations, already have been cancelled within the manuscript and replaced. This Digital Mitford edition has made the manuscript widely available for the first time, and it will no doubt be welcomed by scholars. However, the manuscript, even when the cancelled text is restored, should not be taken as representing Mitford's true or original concept of the play, as this version had already been extensively revised from the play she first brought to Macready in November 1824. The 1828 edition comes from the first print edition of the play. It contains more detailed stage directions than the other editions and indicates the passages that were cut from performances but were retained in print. For scholars of theatrical history and twenty-first-century companies returning Rienzi to the stage, the 1824 edition is invaluable. It should also be noted, however, that this edition is probably the least true to Mitford's intentions, as comparisons to both the manuscript from her hand and to the 1854 edition show quite a few errors and changes from Mitford's syntax. The 1854 edition was edited by Mitford for the first volume of her Dramatic Works, and is our best indication of how Mitford wanted the play to be remembered. In the opinion of this editor, the 1854 edition should be considered the authoritative edition of the play and for that reason additional contextual notes have been included in this edition to assist students and the general public. Each edition, however, has its own import and Digital Mitford has made each of these editions available so that scholars and the public might decide for themselves.

org.note: Powerful aristocratic family in medieval and early modern Rome. Originating in the eleventh century, the Colonnas built a fortified palace (starting in the thirteenth century) at the site of the modern Piazza SS. Apostoli. Percy Shelley claimed to have visited the Colonna palace, and the family features in a minor way in Percy Bysshe Shelley's play The Cenci (1819).

From 737-1968, the official theater censor's office, overseen by the Lord Chamberlain. This function was abolished in 1968, and the office continues in service of different purposes, primarily event-planning (royal appearances, events, and parties.) Mitford's plays were reviewed by this office.

bibl.title: Romeo and Juliet
bibl.author: William Shakespeare
bibl.note: Shakespeare's tragedy, first published in 1597 in a quarto edition that is missing some of the play's most iconic speeches, and subsequently in the second quarto (1599).

bibl.title: The Cenci: A Tragedy, in Five Acts
bibl.author: Percy Bysshe Shelley
bibl.note: Percy Bysshe Shelley's only completed stage play was written in 1819, informed by the legend of Beatrice Cenci, a historical Roman noblewoman who, in 1599, was executed along with her stepmother and brother for the murder of her reportedly abusive father, Count Francesco Cenci. Inspired by a manuscript translated from the Italian by Mary Shelley (who also claimed to have "discussed" with her husband the play's scene breakdown), The Cenci tells a powerful story of political tyranny, incestuous rape, and violent, quickly-suppressed revolt. The play's depiction of rape, incest, and parricide was the apparent cause of its rejection by the Theatre at Covent Garden. It was not produced until 1886, when it premiered in an unlicensed London performance organized by the actress Alma Murray, who played Beatrice.

bibl.title: Isabella, or the Pot of Basil
Lamia, Isabella, The Eve of St. Agnes, and Other Poems
bibl.author: John Keats
bibl.note: Keats's narrative poem is adapted from the tale of Isabella and Lorenzo from Giovanni Boccaccio's Decameron (IV, 5). The poem was first collected in Lamia, Isabella, The Eve of St. Agnes, and Other Poems.

bibl.title: The Fall of Robespierre: An Historic Drama
bibl.author: Robert Southey
Samuel Taylor Coleridge
bibl.note: Three-act historical drama collaboratively written by Samuel Taylor Coleridge and Robert Southey. At the time of the play's writing, it was printed by radical Benjamin Flower but never performed. The play, drafted soon after Robespierre's death, presents a complex portrait of Maximilien Robespierre, political architect (and eventual victim) of the Reign of Terror that followed the French Revolution. This play proved an embarrassment to Southey after his repudiation of his youthful radicalism.

bibl.title: The Prelude, or, Growth of a Poet's Mind: An Autobiographical Poem
bibl.author: William Wordsworth
bibl.note: Autobiographical narrative poem, originally intended to introduce a poetic work that he never completed, first drafted in 1798-1799. The first printed version was an expanded, fourteen-part text published after Wordsworth's death in 1850. A thirteen-book version of 1805 was discovered and printed in 1926.

bibl.title: The Revolt of Islam: A Poem, in Twelve Cantos
bibl.author: Percy Bysshe Shelley
bibl.note: The second published version of a poem that Percy Bysshe Shelley originally titled Laon and Cythna, or, the Revolution of the Golden City. A prophetic vision of a fictional revolution postdating the French Revolution and taking place in the Ottoman Empire, The Revolt of Islam is distinguished by Shelley's self-censorship of his own most controversial material.

bibl.title: Rienzi, The Last of the Roman Tribunes
bibl.author: Edward Bulwer-Lytton
bibl.note: Edward Bulwer-Lytton's novel; a 1835 treatment of the rebellion of Cola di Rienzi, the subject of Mitford's play Rienzi. The novel incorporates some of Mitford's innovations, such as the invention of several female characters.

bibl.title: Rienzi, der Letzte der Tribunen
Rienzi, the Last of the Tribunes
bibl.author: Richard Wagner
bibl.note: Richard Wagner's opera; an 1842 treatment of the rebellion of Cola di Rienzi, the subject of Mitford's play Rienzi.
